reviewText: Let me start by saying that I think Carlin was one of the funniest, cleverest people around, and one of the smartest comedy writers around, with an uncanny ear for rhythm; and furthermore I have agreed with his political, religious, and social stances as portrayed in his comedy.But this was apparently Carlin's first HBO special after 9/11.  Every comedian in the world was treading on thin ground at the time--the death of so many people in such a horrifying way made comedy very difficult--even comedy that had nothing to do with any issue related to the catastrophe.And Carlin has ALWAYS done social/political stuff.What was he to do?He confronts the issue right away, saying that he has to 'get something out of the way so we can have fun', and then goes into a comedic bit about how he would deal with bin Laden and his ilk.  Unfortunately he literally can't be clever about it--the audience didn't want to hear what Carlin wanted to say, and he knew it.So he made fart jokes instead.Admittedly, when he gets going on his rhythmic lists of 'not just any guys, but...', he is very funny...but...fart jokes?  It's not worthy of Carlin.  That's a joke for 5th graders.And I felt that the rest of the show suffered the same problems, and had the same strengths.  When Carlin gets fired up on his variations on a theme (the "and here's another guy who should be strangled at birth with his own umbilical cord..." sort of thing), he's both outrageous and hilarious.  But he lost the audience several times--and at one point he drops a bit before he's finished, saying "I sense I've lost you."I did not care for his 'why you shouldn't stop after you've hit someone with your car' bit, although it had some good moments; and the end of the show was very weak.  Now, this audience loved Carlin, they came knowing him and they were fairly positive even on some of his weakest material--you could tell they wanted to laugh.  But there were a surprisingly large number of times when they just didn't.Having said that, I must also give Carlin credit for having been one of the most polished comedians around--he knew his material backwards and forwards and upside down on fire, and there was never a stammer on the rhythmic delivery of some very lengthy and complex material.  Any comedian would do well to study this performance to see how that is done by the master--ever since his "Seven Words You Can't Say on Television" bit, this has been Carlin's great strength.
summary: The Terrorists Have Won, They Ruined George Carlin

reviewText: Carlin was always acting like a bitter old man and people call that "funny."  I saw the act "Religion is b. s." and "abortion," and there was no humor, just sarcastic support for his own wicked ways.  The "invisible man in the sky" came down and took on human form in the person of Jesus Christ.  Yet, Carlin rejected the faith which has as its symbol "a guy nailed to two pieces of wood."  Carlin also thought he could improve the ten commandments.  Well, first of all, that guy nailed to two pieces of wood wanted to atone for Carlin's sins so he wouldn't be judged by them on the other side of the grave.  And with respect to the ten commandments, Carlin perpertrated the idiocy of juwes by observing the letter of the law and ignoring the spirit of the law.  For, if you loved God and neigbhor, you wouldn't break the commandments.  For love is the heart of the commandments.  God says He sees no pleasure in the death of the wicked.  Carlin was a foolish man, and we can only hope he repented before he died.

reviewText: George Carlin does it again in this Live performance , We sure miss you George . No other Comedian could put fact, common sense , and intelligence into a comedy act. George always puts down the Government ,religion , people and everything else in between. He tries to get the audience involved in his acts as well .By getting under the skin of some people  like businessmen ,politicians, abortions and more. This DVD is no different and continues this great style of comedy. If only George was still alive now he would have some great material today .You have to watch George with a open mind, and if you are easily offended you will not like George, because he tells the truth and the truth hurts even if you laugh at it.

reviewText: I had just heard of George Carlin about a month ago and I read his book "Napalm & Silly Putty"I couldn't stop laughing. So, I rented this and this is one of the funniest things i've ever seen in my entire life. I was laughing so hard, if I had low bladder control, I probably would've pissed my pants. George Carlin takes your everyday thing from fungal growth to little kids on answering machines and turns them into deliriously funny stuff. His one liners are great and his monolouges are just hysterical. If you like crude humor, YOU NEED TO SEE THIS DVD. A+.

reviewText: For my money there are but a few truly legendary comedians who worked from 1970 on: Pryor, Bill Hicks, Chris Rock, Sam Kinison (hit and miss but incredible when really on) and the original master, Carlin. This is a good outing by Carlin as always, with some excellent material and plenty of laughs and sharp observations throughout. But seeing as it was done in NYC two months after 9/11/01, I'm really disappointed in Carlin's brain simply accepting what we were told about the events that day, and basically kissing the government's ass.Imagine if Pryor or Hicks had had a chance to do the same gig on that day. They would have pulled no punches and gone deeper into things, but George pussies out and plays to the party line. Too bad. I see him as a social commentator as much as a comedian, and I wish he'd had the wonderfully sour attitude towards America here as he had on the gloriously dark Life Is Worth Losing, at the end of his life. Instead he gives us some lame "Get Osama" stuff and shows that he was as easily fooled by what he read as most at the time.Aside from that, there's lots of good wordplay as always---Carlin remains untouched in that arena---and plenty of other pretty smart stuff. Well worth watching, no doubt, but far from his best HBO special.
summary: Typically excellent Carlin, but he missed some big chances post-9/11

reviewText: I am so glad I was able to purchase this DVD as I live in Australia where George Carlin is not available.  I've loved Carlin since college...and the older I get, the more I appreciate his irreverent, caustic, "anti"politically correct take on life.  For Carlin lovers, I recommend this one.  If you don't know his humor, don't stay in the dark any longer! Go get a copy of this DVD immediately!
